learning_outcomes.description: Successfully use a range of music creation apps and software.
Collaborate with others within contexts which involve music technology.
Record, mix and produce audio and MIDI using professional audio software and equipment.
reflect critically on practice, analyse and evaluate experiences and actions.
Understand the ways music technology is employed across professional and classroom contexts.

assessments.due_date:
PP1 - Recording in Audacity 18/08/2025 - 22/08/2025

PP2 - Arranging MIDI in Live 8/09/2025 - 12/09/2025

PP3 - Performing with GarageBand 6/10/2025 - 10/10/2025

See Blackboard for the most current information on the assessment schedule.
assessments.task_description:
Complete three in-class tasks on music technology skills. Tasks are collaborative and practical, each focusing on particular technologies and skills introduced during the course.

For each task, follow the brief received at the beginning of the lab session, and complete the task by the end of the lab session.

* PP1 Recording Audio in Audacity

* PP2 Arranging MIDI in Ableton

* PP3 Performing with GarageBand


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: Workshops will be held in timetabled Lab classes during Weeks 11, 12, and 13. Students will form pairs and self-allocate a workshop date and topic during Week 5 via an online sign-up sheet . From Week 6 onward, the allocated date is firm and can only be changed via an official extension request.
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Practical/ Demonstration, Presentation
assessments.task_description:
Facilitate a Workshop

In a group of two, facilitate a 30-minute workshop during your scheduled lab class, introducing peers to a particular technology, app, or software.


Timeline

In Week 5: Self-allocate a workshop date and topic via the sign-up sheet.

Before your allocated workshop date: Conduct independent research to thoroughly learn and understand the allocated technology. Plan an engaging 30-minute workshop session, including demonstrations, explanations, and interactivity.

On your allocated workshop date: With your partner, facilitate a 30-minute workshop on your allocated topic. Take charge of timing, classroom engagement, and technology management. Submit your workshop plan to Blackboard.

During Weeks 11, 12, and 13: Participate in classmates' workshops and provide feedback on each workshop via a questionnaire. The feedback from the questionnaires will form qualitative data for use in the final essay.


Topics

The following workshop topics will be available for allocation:

Week 11 Peer Workshops - iPad Apps

* Koala Sampler

* ThumbJam

* Loopy HD

Week 12 Peer Workshops - Ableton Push Functions

* Ableton Push (playing instruments)

* Ableton Push (playing drums)

* Ableton Push (session control)

Week 13 Peer Workshops - Misc. Demonstrations

* Korg Volca

* Synth

* Audacity

* MuseScore

* Zoom H4n

* Free choice (consult with Tutor)


Marking Criteria

* Operation 30%

* Technical Understanding 30%

* Communication 20%

* Quality of Feedback (on others’ workshops) 20%


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit your workshop plan (maximum 5 pages) to blackboard on your workshop date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will write a 2000-word essay on the following question:

Reflecting on your allocated technology from the Peer Workshops, consider how this technology contributes to meaningful musical experiences.

Draw upon your own experience using the technology, the qualitative data obtained through Peer Workshop Questionnaires, and wider scholarly research.

Discuss both the strengths and limitations of the technology.


Your essay must:

  • Be within 10% of the word count (1800-2200 words).
  • Draw upon at least 5 scholarly references.
  • Draw upon data collected from your workshop questionnaire.
  • Draw upon your own experience.
  • Adhere to reflective essay style (formal academic language/introduction-body-conclusion structure/use of "I" is permitted where appropriate).
  • Conform to the UQ School of Music Style Guide for referencing and formatting.
  • Be saved as .doc or .pdf for submission (no .pages please).


Submit the essay as a via the submission link on Blackboard.


Marking Criteria

* Understanding 35%

* Research 35%

* Communication 30%


Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit PDF or Word Document to Blackboard Submission Link.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

Research Tutorial
